title: New tube maps show how long it takes to walk between stations
text:
Walking steps between stations in zones 1-3 (Picture: TFL) With severe delays or strikes a sadly common occurrence on the London Underground, walking sometimes seems like a more viable option. 
Well, two years after introducing their first handy guide, Transport for London have introduced two new maps for those look to take the healthier option.
Boy, 5, gets stuck inside claw toy-grabbing machine The maps, which now extend down to zone three, shows how long it takes to stroll between stations and how many steps it’ll take.
And for those changing to a train, there is also another map which shows how long it takes to walk to National Rail stations too.
The longest walk takes 44 minutes between Canning Town and North Greenwich on the Jubilee Line otherwise its a more manageable eight to fifteen for most stations.
Walking time between stations in zones 1-3 (Picture: TFL) The release of the updated map coincided with TfL’s first ever walking conference – discussing how London can be made better for pedestrians.
Leon Daniels, who is managing director of surface transport at TfL, said: ‘We recognise the influence that travel choices have on how healthy people can be in London.
Cadbury spends all day explaining why its chocolate is halal ‘If we do things differently, such as helping to reduce car use by providing nicer places to walk, live and work, we can help deliver amazing health benefits to Londoners.
‘Our new Walking Tube map is designed to help people who want to get more active and try making more of their journey round on foot.’
